Name: MECARBAM
Description: Mecarbam is an organic thiophosphate that is O,O-diethyl hydrogen phosphorodithioate in which the hydrogen attached to a sulfur is replaced by a 2-[(ethoxycarbonyl)(methyl)amino]-2-oxoethyl group. It has a role as an EC 3.1.1.7 (acetylcholinesterase) inhibitor, an acaricide and an agrochemical. It is an organic thiophosphate, an organothiophosphate insecticide and a carbamate ester.

plant_concentrations.References: KURIBAYASHI S; ON ADHESION AND RESIDUE OF INSECTICIDE APPLIED TO MULBERRY TREES; KANTO TOSAN BYOGAICHU KENKYUKAI NENPO (PROC KANTO TOSAN PLANT PROTECT SOC) 20: 174-5 (1973)
plant_concentrations.Value: THE ADHESION & RESIDUE OF INSECTICIDE APPLIED TO MULBERRY TREE LEAVES WERE STUDIED. FOR MECARBAM, INITIAL AMT WAS 27.9 PPM & AFTER 20 DAYS RESIDUAL AMT WAS 0.05 PPM.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Meylan WM, Howard PH; J Pharm Sci 84: 83-92 (1995) (2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 5-4, 5-10 (1990) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF value of 32 was calculated for mecarbam(SRC), using an estimated log Kow of 2.29(1,SRC) and a recommended regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF value suggests that bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is moderate, not high(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Bro-Rasmussen F et al; Pestic Sci 1: 179-82 (1970) (2) Nash RG; in Conserv Res Rep (US Dep Agric) 26(Creams, Field Scale Model Chem., Runoff Erosion Agric Manage Syst): 560-94 (1980)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Mecarbam added to a loam soil in a closed system had a half-life of 77 days(1); when added to field sites, an average half-life of 13 days was reported during June-July(1). The rate of degradation slowed considerably during August-September and was very low for October-November(1). Mecarbam residues remaining after 10 months averaged 4%(1). Degradation of this compound may have been due to both biodegradation and hydrolysis(SRC). Mecarbam added to a composite soil had a Ks value of 0.0495, where the Ks value is a constant which measures the rate of dissipation of mecarbam(2).

mechanism_of_action.References: Gosselin, R.E., R.P. Smith, H.C. Hodge. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 5th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1984., p. III-337
mechanism_of_action.Value: Parathion & its relatives are known to inhibit the enzyme cholinesterase in all parts of the body by phosphorylating the active site. /Parathion & other cholinesterase inhibitor pesticides/

mechanism_of_action.References: Dreisbach, R.H. Handbook of Poisoning. 12th ed. Norwalk, CT: Appleton and Lange, 1987., p. 113
mechanism_of_action.Value: Organophosphorus derivatives act by combining with and inactivating the enzyme acetylcholinesterase. ... The inactivation of cholinesterase by cholinesterase inhibitor pesticides allows the accumulation of large amounts of acetylcholine, with resultant widespread effects that may be ... separated into 4 categories: (1) Potentiation of postganglionic parasympathetic activity. (2) Persistent depolarization of skeletal muscle ... (3) Initial stimulation following depression of cells of central nervous system ... (4) Variable ganglionc stimulation or blockade ... /Cholinesterase inhibitor pesticides/

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Meylan WM, Howard PH; J Pharm Sci 84: 83-92 (1995) (2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 4-9 (1990) (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of mecarbam is estimated as approximately 420(SRC), using an estimated log Kow of 2.29(1,SRC) and a regression-derived equation(2,SRC). According to a recommended classification scheme(3), this estimated Koc value suggests that mecarbam has moderate mobility in soil(SRC).

plant_translocations.content: The penetration and translocation of vamidothion, dimethoate, disulfoton, thiometon, and mecarbam in rice plants were investigated using 32P-labeled compounds. Specifically, emulsifiable concentrates of these insecticides were applied to the soil surface of rice plants, and the penetration, translocation, and accompanying insecticidal activity were examined. The results showed that disulfoton exhibited high concentrations in the underground parts of the rice plant shortly after application, indicating rapid penetration into the underground parts. Dimethoate showed almost equal concentrations in both the above-ground and underground parts, suggesting that it can easily penetrate and translocate within the plant body. In contrast, the penetration and translocation of vamidothion were gradual, while those of thiometon and mecarbam were weak. The increase in mortality of the green rice leafhopper (Nephotettix cincticeps) in an insecticide bioassay conducted using the same application method corresponded roughly to the increase in insecticide concentrations in the above-ground parts. At the end of the experiment (6 days after application), residues of vamidothion were low.
plant_translocations.reference: 石黒丈雄, & 斎藤哲夫. (1971). The Fundamental Research to the Application of Systemic Insecticides (II). The Absorption and Translocation of Several Insecticides in Rice Plant by Soil Application. 防虫科学, 36(1), 17-24.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Air-dried paddy field soil, watered as prescribed
method.Chemical Preparation: Sulfur powder, methanol, and ammonia were added to 22.4 mCi/g of S-p-dimethyl phosphite to form an ammonium salt of 32p-0,0-dimethylthiophosphate. 54.5 mCi/g of potassium salt of S2p-diethyl dithiophosphate was dissolved in acetone and added equimolar ethyl mercaptoethyl chloride or chloroacetyl-N-methylurethane to give 82p-Disulfoton, 0,0-diethylS-(2-ethylmercapto)ethylphosphorodithioate and 2p-Mecarbam, 0,0-diethylS(N-ethoxycarbonyl-N-methylcarbamoylmethyl)phosphorodithioate. Each compound was dissolved in chloroform and washed with water before being concentrated to dryness. Purity of each compound was determined by means of distribution of radioactivity in silica gel thin-layer chromatography and colorimetric determination with palladium chloride. Some compounds were further purified with thin-layer chromatography. Each compound was added to aceton:benzene:Newcoa 1863 at a ratio of 30:30:30 W/W to make a 10% emulsifiable concentration.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Each compound, at a 10% emulsifiable concentration, was diluted to 0.05% with distilled water. After 2 days from transplanting, the diluted solution of each compound was evenly distributed onto the soil surface at a rate of 20 mL (as active ingredient) per petri dish. The plants were not directly contaminated with the solution. The rice plants were kept in a growth chamber set at 25°C with a 10-W fluorescent lamp and supplied with water to maintain the water surface at a constant level.
